Replies.Reply: He's dead, Chance! The Old Man's dead!
That Old Man's layin' up there dead as hell and it just don't make any difference to you!
Wait up! I'm goin' out that door first.

Gobbledegook! All the time he talked gobbledegook! An' it's for sure a White man's world in America, hell, I raised that boy since he was the size of a pissant an' I'll say right now he never learned to read an' write - no sir!

Yes, I know the garden very well. I have worked in it all my life. It is a good garden and a healthy one; its trees are healthy and so are its shrubs and flowers, as long as they are trimmed and watered in the right seasons. The garden needs a lot of care. I do agree with the President; everything in it will grow strong, and there is plenty of room in it for new trees and new flowers of all kinds.
Yes. We need a very good gardener.
I understand.

I am a very serious gardener.
Yes. Thank you, Perkins.

Mr. Chance, I'm very pleased to meet you.

What about money?

Might you have a birth certificate, Mr. Chance?

It is quite amazing how those clothes have come back into style.
Good day, Mr. Chance.
Your lunch? You have a luncheon appointment here?
You live here?
Since you were a child?
Do you have any proof of your employment, Mr. Chance - any checks from the deceased, any contracts or documents?
How were you compensated for these duties you say you performed?
How were you paid?
Mr. Chance, perhaps you could show us some identification with your address -- a Driver's License, a credit card, checkbook?
Then how about medical records?
Mr. Chance, that was twenty-seven years ago.
Come now, Mr. Jennings had been bedridden for thirty-five years, since he fractured his spine.
Have you served in the Army?
Are you related to the deceased, Mr. Chance?
Mr. Chance, the fact remains that we have no information of your having any connection with the deceased.
What are your plans now, Mr.
Mr. Chance, assuming what you say is the truth, I would like to know what sort of claim you are planning to make against the deceased's estate.
Good. That's good. Then if you would please sign a paper to that effect.
Come now, Mr. Chance.
But you won't sign, correct?
I think you do, Mr. Chance.
It's that gardener!
No! He's a real gardener!
Okay, I'll see you in twenty minutes.
Yeah? Well, I don't understand what was up his sleeve when he pulled that stunt with us? What was he doing? And why?
Another thing that baffles me, Doctor - what was his connection with the deceased? Major financial dealings, obviously - but our firm has no record of any such transactions.
Well, he said it was his, he walked us through it.
Of course, Doctor, I understand.
Certainly, glad to be of help.
What you growin', man?
Bullshit. Who sent you here, boy?
Dead, my ass! Now get this, honkie -
You got that, boy?
Now, move, honkie! Before I cut your white ass!
Yes sir. I'll report it right away.
Good day.
Perhaps I should call an ambulance.
I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. Rand, I never saw the man.
Thank you, ma'am.
Can you walk? It's not broken, is it?
I don't think we should call anyone just yet, it may not even be all that serious.
Let's have a look, do you mind?
It's starting to swell, is it painful?
Please, sir.
I assure you, sir, David is a very careful driver. Please, won't you let us take you?
Very good.
Yes sir. I'll take care of that.
Yes ma'am.
Look!
Somebody ought to call the police!
Why, there certainly is. You must see a doctor, I insist on it.
I hope you're comfortable.

These can be such trying situations everyone seems to make such a to-do over a simple little accident. Of course, they can be very frightening, and I must apologize for David, he's never had an accident before.
I see.
Yes. My husband has been very ill.
David, we'll just go on home.
Would you care for a drink?
Oh, by the way - I'm Eve Rand.
May I ask your name?
Pardon me, was that Mr. Chance?
Oh. Well, they're just a wonderful couple, we've been friends for years. We visit their island quite often.
Did you lose something?
I can see that it must be very important for you to stay informed of all the latest events.
Good evening, Wilson.
Thank you, Wilson. That will be fine.
Thank you, Greta.
I'll be with Mr. Rand if I'm needed.
I'll see you after the doctor has a look at your leg, Mr. Gardiner.
Good evening, Constance.
No headaches?
You heard?
Oh, it wasn't all that bad, darling. We were fortunate that Mr.
Do you feel well enough for that?
I wanted some fresh air, Robert.
Stay here? Is that necessary?
He's very intense, and internal, don't you think?
Won't your injury prevent you from attending to business, Mr.
Oh. I'm very sorry. Well, if you have any need for any of our facilities, please do not hesitate to ask.
I hope that staying here won't be an inconvenience for you.
Oh, I know exactly what you mean. I sometimes enjoy puttering around myself, such a pleasant way to forget one's troubles.
Chauncey, I wanted to tell you how dreadful I feel about the accident today, but that I'm delighted that you are staying with us.
Chauncey!
Your leg must be getting better.
Good. I'm glad to hear that.
Yes, he is. I'm sorry I didn't get to see him.
Was he a relative? Or an intimate friend?
Forgive me, Chauncey - I didn't mean to pry. You must have been very close to him.
Of course.
Our greenhouse.
Yes, so do we.
Chauncey, I just wanted to wish you well. I know you'll be smashing.
And Benjamin sends along his best wishes.
He's tired, Chauncey - but he's going to watch you tonight. We'll both be watching.
Oh. Well, we can fix up one of Ben's for you tomorrow night.
Chauncey! Have you seen the papers?
Well, it seems you've been described as one of the architects of the President's speech. And your own comments from the 'This Evening' show are quoted side by side with the President's.
Oh, come in, Maggie.
Chauncey, Maggie will alter Ben's tuxedo for you now.
I've never seen anyone handle the media as well as you, Chauncey.
Mr. Watson.
Chauncey, this is Mr. Dennis Watson of the State Department.
Hello, Sophie.
Chauncey, this is Mrs. Sophia Rowley.
It seems like ages, Mr. Ambassador.
Mrs. Skrapinov.
He's doing as well as could be expected, Mr. Ambassador. He still speaks of the stimulating discussions he's had with you.
Of course.
Would you two excuse me for a moment?
Everyone wants to meet you.
Chauncey, where have you been? I was afraid you got bored and left, or that you were with some mysterious woman.
It must be the punch, and it is stuffy in here -- I feel it a little myself. You're an angel, my dear - thank God there are still men like you around to give aid and comfort.
One of those little things you don't know about me yet, darling -
Dearest, you uncoil my wants; desire flows within me, and when you watch me my passion dissolves it. You set me free. I reveal myself to myself and I am drenched and purged.
Thank you, Nancy.
We have to find him, Robert - he could be lost, something may have happened, we can't leave him!
There he is! Chauncey!
Chauncey! Chauncey!
Good evening, Mrs. Rand.
I shall take the gentleman to the third floor guest suite, ma'am. Dr.
Yes, ma'am.
No - but Mr. Rand does have one with an electric motor, that way he can get around by himself.
Yes sir, I guess that's true smallest room in the house.
Good morning, Mr. Woltz, nice to see you again.
Fine, thank you.
We have an additional guest with us today, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.
An outstanding speech, sir.
Good evening, Mrs. Rand.
You too, Mr. Rand, you must stay quiet.
No, it's been a good day - better than yours, from what I've been told.
I may be a shut-in, but I do not lack for news. I'm sorry you had to go through all that.
Reasonable? Good, I'd like to meet a reasonable man. Why don't you ask this Gardiner to join us for dinner?
Constance! I want new blood tonight, I'm getting up for dinner.
Don't argue, tell Robert I want new blood!
Welcome to Rand Memorial Hospital, Mr. Gardiner.
Sure you do. This ward is air tight, I have a little extra oxygen pumped in, keeps my spirits up.
Aplastic anemia, Mr. Gardiner -
I am very sick, and, as you can see by all this paraphernalia, I am very wealthy. I think I would rather be wealthy and sick than poor and sick.
I know exactly what you mean. Today the businessman is at the mercy of kid-lawyers from the SEC. All they want to do is regulate our natural growth! It's happening across the country!
Of course! By kid-lawyers!
Do you need a secretary?
Oh. When you say 'Your house has been closed', you mean to say that your business was shut down?
What'd I tell you? Kid-lawyers! The S.E.C.! Damn them!
That's good, Mr. Gardiner. Or may I call you Chauncey?
And I'm Ben.
So tell me, Chauncey, what are your plans now?
Do we have a garden? Hah! Tomorrow, Chauncey, you will see our gardens.

A gardener! Well put, Chauncey excellent! Isn't that what a businessman is? A gardener? A person that makes flinty soil productive with the labor of his own hands, who waters it with the sweat from his own brow, and who creates a place of value for his family and community? Yes, Chauncey, what a brilliant metaphor -- yes, indeed, a productive businessman is a laborer in his own vineyard.
Bravo!

Now, wait a minute, Chauncey you are young, you are healthy, for God's sake don't give up on yourself! You have to fight! You can't let those bastards keep you down! I don't want to hear any more from you about the 'Room Upstairs'.
Yes, I'm sure it is. That's what they say, anyway.
Reluctant to speak, eh, Chauncey?
Robert, take a look, would you?
We have common foes, Chauncey - kid lawyers and our physician!
Chauncey, up and around this morning, are you?
Well, that's good news, my boy.
No one likes a dying man, my boy -
He's here.
Yes, Mrs. Aubrey?
Fine. Show the President to the library, we'll be along in a few minutes.
Not now, Teresa. I'm seeing the President on my own two feet.
Shall we go, Chauncey?
Mrs. Aubrey, have you received the papers on the Caracas agreement?
A good woman, Mrs. Aubrey.
Woltz, how have you been?
I'm not convinced of that, Mr.
Mr. President, I'd like you to meet my dear friend, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.
You will find that my house guest does not bandy words, Mr.
Yes, I did.
Overall - pretty good. But, Mr.
I sympathize with your position, Mr. President, I know how difficult it is to be straightforward, the reaction to such a speech could be chaos.
I'm afraid so.
I think what my most insightful friend is saying, Mr. President, is that we welcome the inevitable seasons of nature, yet we are upset by the seasons of our economy.
No, she flew up to Boston for another charity event. She'll be sorry to have missed you.
Nonsense, Mr. President - I thank you for coming to spend time with a dying man.
You're right, Mr. President I don't like feeling sorry for myself.
You take care too, Bobby.
He's a decent fellow, the President, isn't he?
He was quite impressed with your comments, Chauncey - he hears my sort of analysis from everyone, but yours, unfortunately - seldom if ever at all.

Oh, sure you do, the financial assistance program. I think you might be just the man to take charge of such an undertaking. I'd like you to meet with the members of the Board, we'll be able to discuss the matter at greater length at that time.
And, please, Chauncey - don't rush your decision. I know you're not a man to act on the spur of the moment.
And now, Chauncey, I'm afraid you must excuse me - I'm very tired all of a sudden.
Damn, Constance, get in here! You shouldn't miss any of this!
Good. Together, the two of you should create quite a stir - I can already hear the gossip.
Everything. I said everything and that's exactly what I mean.
The injection will ease the pain and swelling, Mr. Gardiner.
Now, you'll barely feel this. It won't hurt at all.
It's good that there was no apparent damage to the bone.
However, with injuries such as this, I have run into minor hemorrhaging, which really isn't too serious at the time, but can cause secondary problems if not looked after.
You can pull your trousers up, now.
Just to take the proper precautions, Mr. Gardiner, I'd recommend we take you downstairs and X-ray your leg.
Yes. Are you planning on making any sort of claim against the Rand's?
Thomas? Who's Thomas?
An attorney?
Then you wish to handle this matter through your attorneys?

Good, keep your weight off that leg, Mr. Gardiner. In fact, it would be best if you could stay here for a day or two, if that would be would be possible. Since Benjamin became ill we have our own hospital downstairs. I can promise you the finest in care, unless, of course, you would prefer to go elsewhere.
Fine. Would you like me to speak to your personal physician?
I'll send Wilson up to take you for X-rays, Mr. Gardiner. Feel free to use the telephone, and please let me know if you have any discomfort.
Good God, Eve - you'll freeze out here.
A rather large contusion, but I don't feel there is any serious damage. I'd like to keep an eye on him, though - I suggested that he stay here for a couple of days.
Not necessary, but preferable. I don't think he'll be a bother, he seems like a most refreshing sort of man.
How true. Mr. Gardiner may be a welcome change of pace.
At times, yes. But that's not an uncommon reaction to such an accident. Actually, I found him to have quite a sense of humor.
To everyone, I'm afraid. The Government controls are so restricting that the Medical Profession, as we know it, is being legislated out of existence.
Chauncey, there you are. What are you doing on that leg?
Shame on you, Chauncey - you should let me be the judge of that.
Please, sit in the chair.
He does, does he?
Why, that's terrific, Chauncey.
Hell yes - walk. You're meeting the President, aren't you?
Excuse us, please.  Eve and Chance leave the room as Allenby administers aid to Rand.
He's resting comfortably now.
And you, Benjamin, must be strong and brave for me. Turn over, please.
Mr. Thomas Franklin, please.
Is Thomas Franklin in?

Hmmm. You say he showed you his garden?
Mr. Franklin, I must ask you and Miss Hayes to keep this incident with Mr. Gardiner to yourselves.
Fine. Thank you, Mr. Franklin.
It's not good, Ben - I'm sure you can feel it.
Yes, I suppose that's true.
In a day or two, yes.

This won't take long, Mr. Gardiner.
No sir, I don't believe I do.
Yes, sir.
Well, I still don't believe I know the man, Mr. Gardiner. Now, hold still.

Please, hold still, Mr. Gardiner.

Your limousine, sir.
May I help you, Mr. Gardiner?
Oh, Mr. Rand, of course. Right this way, sir.
Good morning, Mr. Wilson.
Thank you. How have you been?
Okay, let's go to work.
Good morning, Mr. Rand.
And you must be Mr. Gardiner.
Just a formality, Mr. Gardiner.
Mr. Gardiner. Mr. Rand would like to see you.
Ben!
It's so good to see you too, Ben, you look terrific!
Here, sit down, get off your feet.
Mr. Gardiner, my pleasure.
I just wondered if you had gone over my speech, Ben.
That's too big a risk, I can't take the chance.
It's that serious, huh?
Do you agree with Ben, Mr.
Could you go through that one more time, please, Mr. Gardiner?
Is Eve around? I'd like to say hello.
I'm sorry, too. Well, Nancy wanted me to send along her best to the two of you - and, Ben, I want to thank you for your time and thoughts.
Now, Ben, I won't have any of that.
Take care of yourself, Ben.
Kaufman, I'm going to need information on Mr. Chauncey Gardiner's background.
And put it through on a Code Red -
He's an advisor and close personal friend of Rand's! For Christ sakes, they have volumes of data on Benjamin!

I do not want Benjamin Rand disturbed! You have other ways of gathering information than to trouble a dying man. Use whatever agencies are necessary to put together a detailed history of Chauncey Gardiner, if you run into problems, alert Honeycutt.
I'll be in the office at seven in the morning and I would like to have it at that time.
I've got to take a leak.
Gloomy predictions? That insolent son of a bitch!
Good morning, gentlemen.
This is not what I requested.
This information goes back three days. I want the standard file, you know that.
What the hell are you talking about, Kaufman?
I'd like to hear that data, Kaufman.
Miss Davis - I'd like my eggs poached this morning, please.
I would appreciate that.
Oh? What?
Good. Anything else?
No, that won't do any good.
Yeah, Kaufman - what is it?
Chief, we have a break in the case.
What? Why?
I can't say at this time - neither agency will admit to a thing.
Okay, get both Directors over here, I'll be right down.

Gentlemen, I didn't call you here at such an hour to make accusations, I just want to explore the possibilities. Now, I have three questions; Is the man a foreign agent? Or, have we suddenly found that our methods of gathering data are grossly inefficient? Or, thirdly, have the man's files been destroyed? Now, I'd like some answers.
I see. What about question three?
And what do the boys around Intelligence think?
Gentlemen, needless to say, there is going to be a full Congressional investigation of your respective operations.
Good night.

I initially came in contact with the Rand name in 1943. 1 was a young lieutenant in the Air Corps, a navigator flying missions over Europe. That plane that I learned to know so well was manufactured by the Rand Aeronautics Corporation.
Good morning. I'm Riff, Secret Service.
Gardiner, yes, sir.
No problem, Chief.
Right, Chief.
No, sir.
Right, Chief.
Well, we do have data from Honeycutt's sources, Chief - but it isn't pertinent.
Yes, sir.
Sorry to disturb you, chief but we have new developments.

Fine, then let's get started. The current state of our country is of vital interest to us all, and I would like to know if you agree with the President's view of the economy?
Come now, Mr. Gardiner, before his speech at the Financial Institute the President consulted with you and Benjamin Rand, did he not?
I know that, Mr. Gardiner.

Well, let me rephrase the question; the President compared the economy of this country to a garden, and stated that after a period of decline a time of growth would naturally follow. Do you go along with this belief?
Let's make it clear, Mr. Gardiner, it's your view that the collapse of the Stock Market, the dramatic increase in unemployment, you feel that this is just another season, so to speak, in the garden?
I think your metaphors are quite interesting, Mr. Gardiner, but, haven't we seen seasons that have been devastating to certain countries?
Such as disasterous winters, prolonged droughts that have wiped out crops, hurricanes that have all but swept away island communities?
Don't we need a leader capable of guiding us through the seasons? The bad as well as the good?
Do you feel that we have a 'Very good gardener' in office at this time, Mr. Gardiner?
I realize that might be a difficult question for you, Mr. Gardiner -
I'm sorry to say that our time is running short, but before we close, I'd like to ask one final question.
Yes, Chauncey Gardiner.
He does talk like one, but I think he's brilliant.
Good night.
I said good night!
I'll call you soon.
